Map shows average yearly counts of lightning flashes per square kilometre from 1995 to 2013. The Democratic Republic of Congo was found to have the most over the period. The map was created by Nasa's Tropical Rainfall Measuring Mission satellite. It shows the areas with the largest number of flashes. They are up to 150 per year per square kilometre (0.4 square miles). And the highest frequency over land is because solid earth absorbs sunlight and heats up faster than water.
